required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Mechanical Ventilation in the Emergency Department: A Prospective Cross-Sectional Study
clinical_study.official_title: Mechanical Ventilation in the Emergency Department: A Prospective Cross-Sectional Study

brief_summary.textblock: Despite its life-saving potential, the mechanical ventilator has great potential to do harm. Despite years of research, the mortality in acute lung injury (ALI) remains very high. Treatment options after ALI onset are very limited, therefore prevention may be the best option. Unfortunately, the emergency department has not been studied with respect to mechanical ventilation practices, and its contribution to ALI is unknown. The investigators hypothesize that mechanical ventilation is frequently used in the ED and for a variety of reasons, and that ED mechanical ventilation has an effect on long term outcomes.

primary_outcome.measure: The epidemiology and incidence of mechanical ventilation in critically ill ED patients
primary_outcome.description: In a prospective cross-sectional study design, we will enroll all patients receiving mechanical ventilation in the ED over a one-month time frame.

secondary_outcome.measure: The incidence of acute lung injury in mechanically ventilated emergency department patients

arm_group.arm_group_label: All ED patients requiring mechanical ventilation

intervention.intervention_name: For inclusion in the study, patients will have to require mechanical ventilation either via an endotracheal tube or tracheostomy tube.
intervention.description: Mechanical ventilation via an endotracheal tube or tracheostomy tube
intervention.arm_group_label: All ED patients requiring mechanical ventilation

study_pop.textblock: Patients presenting to the emergency department requiring invasive mechanical ventilation.

overall_official.affiliation: Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis

facility.name: University of Iowa College of Medicine
University of Cincinnati College of Medicine

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor of Anesthesiology and Emergency Medicine
